q1.description: Start with the alphabet set. We normally represent an alphabet set with $\Sigma$. The alphabet set is a set of symbols (typically letters or characters, but it could include any symbols}.
q1.question: Which of the following are  alphabet sets?

q111.question: [T/F] c) $A$ is not the answer because it is just a character

q2.description: Given some alphabet set $\Sigma$, a string is a finite sequence of symbols (taken from $\Sigma$, of course). Suppose we have $\Sigma = \{a, b\}$, which of the following are valid strings?
q2.question: Suppose we have $\Sigma$ = $\{a, b\}$, which of the following are valid strings?

q2_2.description: Given some alphabet set $\Sigma$, a string is a finite sequence of symbols (taken from $\Sigma$, of course). Suppose we have $\Sigma = \{a, b\}$
q2_2.question: Does $\{aaa, bbb\}$ a valid string?
q2_2.answer: No, because $\{aaa, bbb\}$ is a set
choices: Yes, it is a valid string
No, because $\{aaa, bbb\}$ is a set

q2_3.description: Given some alphabet set $\Sigma$, a string is a finite sequence of symbols (taken from $\Sigma$, of course). Suppose we have $\Sigma = \{a, b\}$
q2_3.question: [T/F] The choice $bacbabcba$ is not a vaild string in $\Sigma$
q2_3.answer: It is not a valid string as it includes letter not in $\Sigma$
choices: It is not a valid string as it includes letter not in $\Sigma$

q3.description: A $\textit{language}$ is simply a collection of strings defined over $\Sigma$.
q3.question: Which of the following are correct languages over their $\Sigma$?

q3_2.description: A language is simply a collection of strings defined over $\Sigma$.
q3_2.question: Can $\Sigma$=$\{a,b,c\}$ $L = ab$ be a language?

q3_3.description: A language is simply a collection of strings defined over $\Sigma$.
q3_3.question: Can $\Sigma$=$\{a,b,c\}$ $L = \{a\}$ be a language?

q3_4.description: A language is simply a collection of strings defined over $\Sigma$.
q3_4.question: Can $\Sigma$=$\{a,b,c\}$ $L$ = $\{\}$ be a language?

q3_5.description: Good, since a language is just a set of strings, the empty set is a perfectly good language.
q3_5.question: Oh, and remember that we have a special symbol for “empty” set. Which is it?

q4.description: Another definition of a language is a subset of the powerset of $\Sigma$. Remember from Discrete Math class that a power set of any set is the set of all possible subsets from the given set.
q4.question: Choose what can be the power set of $\{a, b\}$

q5.description: Useful notations: We usually use these symbols in our book, For symbols in some alphabet $\Sigma$, we typically use either digits or letters near the start of the common English alphabet: $a,b,c,d,0,1$ For string names (that is, some variable that is meant to refer to a string), we usually use letters near the end of the common English alphabet: $u,v,w,x,y,z$
q5.question: So, when you see $b$ in a sentence, it probably refers to

q5_1.description: Useful notations: We usually use these symbols in our book, For symbols in some alphabet $\Sigma$, we typically use either digits or letters near the start of the common English alphabet: $a,b,c,d,0,1$ For string names (that is, some variable that is meant to refer to a string), we usually use letters near the end of the common English alphabet: $u,v,w,x,y,z$
q5_1.question: And if you see w in a sentence, it probably refers to

q6.description: There are some basic string operations we will use a lot. The size of a string is the number of symbols in the string.  We use the operator $|$$|$ to donate the size of the string.
q6.question: Let $w=abbc$, $v=ab$, What is $|w|$ + $|v|$

q7.description: Another important operation is string concatenation. The concatenation of two strings $u$, and v is just the string that contains the symbols of $u$ followed by the symbols of $v$. We use the symbol ∘ to represent concatenation: Example : Let $w$=$a1a2...an$, and $v$=$b1b2...bn$ Then, $w∘v$  = $a1a2...anb1b2...bm$
q7.question: Let $w = abc$, $v = 012$, What is $w∘v$?

q7_1.description: In reality, we use concatenation so much that we hardly ever want to be that formal. When we mean w∘v, we will normally simply write $wv$ instead.
q7_1.question: Let $w = abc$, $v = 012$, What is $wv$?

q8.description: Another form of string concatenation is to concatenate a string with itself. Suppose we have a string $v$.  The notation $v^3$ means concatenate $v$ with itself 3 times. Concatenating a string with itself zero times yields the empty string $\lambda$
q8.question: let $v = ab$, what is $v^3$ ?

q8_1.description: Recall, since a language is just a subset of all possible strings, that the empty set of strings is a language: $L$ = {} = <empty set symbol>.
q8_1.question: Is this a language? $\{\lambda\}$

q9.description: Concatenating any string with $\lambda$  gives the same string. In other words, $\lambda$ is the concatenation identity. For example, $ab$∘$\lambda$=$\lambda$∘$ab$=$ab$
q9.question: What is $\lambda∘acb∘\lambda$?

q10.description: Another useful operation is to reverse a string: Reversing a string means to flip it, in other words, write its symbols in reverse order.
q10.question: Let $w = abbc$, what is $w^R$? Note: R here means reverse

q11.description: Another useful operation is to reverse a string: Reversing a string means to flip it, in other words, write its symbols in reverse order.
q11.question: let $w=abbc$, and $v=ab$. What is $|vv^Rw|$

q12.description: One of the most important operations that we use is the * operator, also called the closure operator. “*” of something means concatenating that something zero or more times. For example, if we have $\Sigma$ = {a,b}, $\Sigma$* means the set of strings obtained by concatenating 0 or more symbols from $\Sigma$.
q12.question: Which of the following are strings in $\Sigma^∗$?

q12_1.description: One of the most important operations that we use is the * operator, also called the closure operator. “*” of something means concatenating that something zero or more times. For example, if we have $\Sigma$ = {a,b}, $\Sigma$* means the set of strings obtained by concatenating 0 or more symbols from $\Sigma$.
q12_1.question: Which are examples of $w^*$ where $w = abc$?

q13.description: Slightly different from the * operator, sometimes we want to have at least one copy of the thing that we are concatenating. Then we use +. One way of thinking of this: $\Sigma$+=$\Sigma$∗−{$\lambda$}
q13.question: Let  $\Sigma = \{a,b\}$, Which of the following are strings in ?

q14.description: Sets. As we see, Languages are sets, so all sets of operations can be applied to them.
q14.question: Let $\sigma$={$a$,$b$,$c$}, $L_1$={$ab$,$bc$,$aba$}, $L_2$={$c$,$bc$,$bcc$}, which element is included in $L_1∪L_2$ ?

q15.description: Sets. As we see, Languages are sets, so all sets of operations can be applied to them.
q15.question: Let $\Sigma=\{a,b,c\}$, $L_1=\{ab,bc,aba\}$, $L_2=\{c,bc,bcc\}$, what is $L_1∩L_2$ ?

q16.description: In languages, $\Sigma^*$  represents the Universe set $U$. For example, the complement of $L$ will be the set of all strings in $\Sigma$ except the strings in $L$. In other words, $\bar{L}$ = $\Sigma^* - L$
q16.question: Let $\Sigma=\{a,b,c\}$, $L_1=\{ab,bc,aba\}$, $L_2=\{c,bc,bcc\}$, what is $\overline{L_1∩L_2}$?

q17.description: Sets concatenation. Concatenating two sets $L1$, and $L2$ means concatenating every string in $L1$ with each string in $L2$.
q17.question: Let $\Sigma=\{a,b,c\}$, $L_1=\{ab,bc,aba\}$, $L_2=\{c,bc,bcc\}$, which of the following is $L_1L_2$?

q18.description: Sets concatenation. Concatenating a set zero times will give the set of the empty string $\lambda$.
q18.question: Let $\Sigma$={$a$,$b$}, $L$={$ab$,$aba$}, What is $L^0$?

q19.description: Sets concatenation. Concatenating a set n times means concatenating every string in L with each string in $L$ n times
q19.question: Let $\Sigma$={$a$,$b$}, $L$={$ab$,$aba$}, What is $L^2$?

q19_1.description: Sets concatenation. Concatenating a set n times means concatenating every string in L with each string in $L$ n times
q19_1.question: Let $\Sigma$=$\{a,b\}$, $L$=$\{ab,aba\}$, What is $L^3$?
q19_1.answer: $\{ababab, abaabaab, abaabab, abaabaab, abababa, ababaaba, abaababa, abaabaaba\}$
choices: $\{ababab, abaabaab, abaabab, abaabaab, abababa, ababaaba, abaababa, abaabaaba\}$
$\{ab, ababaab, abaabab, abaabaab, abababa, abaaba, abaababa, abaabaaba\}$
$\{ababab, baab, abaabab, abaaba, abab, ababaaba, abaababa, abaabaaba\}$
$\{ababab, ababa, abaabab, abaab, ababa, ababaaba, abaababa, abaabaaba\}$
$\{ababab, ababaab, abaabab, abaabaab, baba, ababaaba, abaaba, abaaba\}$
